item.title: Axoloti Control still in dev?
item.dc:creator: @thetechnobear Mark Harris
item.description:
@thetechnobear wrote:

toneburst:

Any more recent news on this? I'm still holding out for the controller.

afaik yes... Johannes had it with him a superbooth, and its a working prototype.

its an interesting 'product' which is trying to tread a fine balance of cost (price) and functionality, where there is no right answer - as every potential user will have a different idea of where that price/functionality should be, depending on many factors.
so not sure if that prototype is what will eventually be released - which i think is why nothing concrete has been said.

also iirc, Johannes said its not seen much development in recent months, due to work on the next axoloti software release - which has the priority (and is also needed for Axoloti Control too)

so still active - but no idea when it'll be released, but be assured Johannes knows its important to alot of users, and important to the axoloti platform.

item.title: Axoloti Control still in dev?
item.dc:creator: @SmashedTransistors
item.description:
@SmashedTransistors wrote:

Yes, the Arduino has lots of libraries (many by Limor Fried) to handle displays.
Even on the Arduino, i think it is better to use "genuine" displays (from Adafruit or Sparkfun) especially concerning touch sensitive TFT displays (i had a bad experience with low cost TFT...).

I recently did a few limited and very specific direct use of small 128x64 OLEDs I2C connected to the Axoloti. Even if it is successful, I must say that it is no easy stuff without libraries. I can't imagine how difficult it would be to control larger TFT displays... and i prefer to use the Axoloti CPU for audio.

A generic controller will be able to deal with parameters and patches and some real time control. Patches designed for it will be shareable with other users.

While custom controllers can add specific features (ribbon controllers, pressure sensitive keyboard, distance sensor, breath controller... Arduino with touch sensitive TFT for live waveterrain synthesis ...)

item.title: Axoloti Control still in dev?
item.dc:creator: @thetechnobear Mark Harris
item.description:
@thetechnobear wrote:

Axoloti Control is still in dev (afaik) .. the last prototype is great. I think pretty close to final hardware form, but some work still needed on firmware (but its working) - but ive no idea on release plans/dates
( bare in mind, it requires both hardware and software development)

yes, Axoloti Control will be complimentary to custom controllers, its connected a dedicated set of pins. x4 (iirc) via a ribbon cable... and uses spi (again iirc)

I think, even for those that have developed their own controllers, it will still be very attractive addition... due to the close tie in with the parameters system , and other 'features'
some will still want custom controllers, e.g. because they want lots of dedicated pots/sliders, but for more generic control its going to be perfect.

so definitely a role for both.

item.dc:creator: @jfcharles Jean-Francois Charles
item.description:

You don't need Arduino to make your controller. With axoloti, you can add up to 15 analog input controls, plus switches, see this page of the User Guide:

Official Pin Outs revised (work in progress) User Guide
I'll be working on revising this post here, I was going to write it in a text document but realized it would be easier for me to get all the images if I just made it here. I was looking for a a save feature so I could wait to post until complete but could not find it. So please note this is all a work in progress and NEEDS further revision/information. GPIO Overview [image] VDD versus VDDA versus VDDC VDD is the digital 3.3V supply, use it to power external logic VDDA is the analog refe…

I find that once you get started using axoloti, you want to use either you own personalized controls, or any existing MIDI controller. The more you use it, the less appeal a generic "axoloti controller" has.
